Posts.Content: When taking radiation, I asked the RO about the return of testosterone after hormone therapy. He said stopping Eligard after two years duration, I would probably regain 20% of what I had before hormone therapy. He did not tell me how long it would take before testosterone would return. I was evaluated as 3tb no. It seems that urologist starting patients never tell the patient that testosterone levels will never return to normal.
Posts.Title: Recovery from Eligard/Lupron hormone therapy??

Posts.Content: I posted earlier today asking about Lupron (Eligard), but then realized that probably no one would identlfy this as the drug as what is used in hormone therapy, so thought I had better make my hormone therapy inquiry understandable to anyone who has been on hormone therapy............... Advise on Lupron (Eligard) usage Met with my uro-surgeon last Thursday. I had Da Vinci 3 months ago, with a slow painful recovery because of lymphocels. I am healing much better now, but latest PSA test produced a 0.22 read out. Doc says that number denotes I still have some PCa. Latest plan is to receive Eligard injections once a month for 6 months. This will put the PCa into remission, and give my surgery additional time to heal, before receiving radiation to kill off PCa. Doctor said side effects of reduced testosterone produced by Eligard, is hot flashes, fatigue, and low sexual desire. At an Eligard website, I found additional effects listed, with numerical percentages. Hot flashes -- in up to 73.3 percent of people Injection site reactions, including mild pain, burning, and stinging -- up to 34.6 percent Fatigue and general discomfort -- up to 17.5 percent Decreased testicle size -- up to 7.2 percent Muscle pain -- up to 4.5 percent Dizziness -- up to 4.4 percent Clamminess -- up to 4.4 percent Weakness -- up to 3.6 percent Breast enlargement -- up to 3.6 percent Nausea -- up to 3.4 percent Joint pain -- up to 3.4 percent. Other common reactions, occurring in 2.2 to 3.3 percent of people, included: Decreased libido (decreased sex drive) Night sweats Pain in the arms or legs Frequent need to urinate Itching Stomach and intestinal irritation ("stomach flu") Getting up in the middle of the night to urinate Hair loss Testicular pain. I would like to hear any testimonials from anyone who has received Eligard. Thanks...........Rooster22
Posts.Title: Hormone therapy for prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Hello Mom, I finished 8 weeks of radiation last April. Radiation is 5 days a week, so it becomes a part time job. I scheduled early morning, so I would have the rest of my day to do what I wanted. Recommend using the rectal balloon, as I believer it limits the amount of radiation that would other wise radiate the colon. Some doctors recommend it, some don't. A little uncomfortable having it installed, but not painful. Would recommend radiation from the Varian Rapid Arc machine, as that machine does a great job of focusing radiation to a specific pelvic area. None of the radiation treatments cause any pain or discomfort in of themselves. It was only in the last week of radiation, that I began to feel some urinary irritation. After radiation, the problem got worse to cause burning pain upon urination. That lasted about six weeks before disappearing. I had no other problems. Many guys have no side effects what so ever. It is important to show up for treatments with a nearly full bladder, and an empty bowel. Some days that was not easy to do. Agree with others to begin radiation upon psa readings steadily increasing. It shows that cancer is growing. Often, hormone therapy is begun before radiation. This puts cancer cells into hibernation, and improves the results of radiation. I hope all goes well.
Posts.Title: Looks like dad's headed to salvage radiation. Your experiences appreciated!

Posts.Content: Yes, RobLee, I think we are in the same boat together. My life has been a good long run too, I just hate accepting the new normal. Yea, I don't miss the body hair at all. A plus is that the bald spot on top of my head has started growing some fuzz. Go figure?? More than anything, I miss the good sex life my wife and I had. Just no erections with non nerve sparing RP. Getting an erection with a vacuum unit is pretty much worthless. I have tried the penile injections. They sort of work, but when I inject, it depresses me to think that my sex life has come down to this. I have looked into penile implants. However, that is major surgery with a good three weeks of painful recovery. I have had enough surgery over the past two years, to not want any more for some time. Enough of my rant. I gotta look forward, and feel blessed that I am in the zero club.

Posts.Content: This topic was discussed (in another) forum. I thought it important enough to present here as well. Dr. Fagan's video makes an interesting presentation. The video is well worth a watch. RALP "Nerve sparing" refers to the bundle of nerves that are wrapped around the prostate like a cobweb. They are responsible for sending the signals that cause an erection. These nerves are the only ones Urologists talk about before a prostatectomy. I did have nerve sparing, but ended up with ED anyway. But there are other nerves that are never mentioned that are part of the erection process, but have not been protected in most or all prostatectomies. The deep branch of the perineal nerve is one such nerve. It is needed to make your erection get hard by triggering muscles that squeeze the internal part of the penis to increase the penis blood pressure, making a rigid erection. Usually a prostatectomy doesn't destroy this nerve, but sometimes, due to variations in men's anatomy, it gets destroyed. You can learn more by watching this video from Dr. Randy Fagan: https://www.facebook.com/NeuroProtec...46839208667459 It shows a new nerve mapping device that can help to save these nerves. I doubt there are very many Urologist surgeons that use this device, which is a shame. I wish I had known about it before my surgery, so I could have insisted on it being used.
Posts.Title: RALP nerve sparing surgery also needs perineal nerve preserved to avoid ED

Posts.Content: I completed 19 months of Eligard Hormone Therapy. Eligard is the same as Lupron, just a different brand name, different manufacturer. Six weeks have elapsed upon completing the 19 months. The hot flashes are less frequent, and less intense. Had my testosterone level tested last week. My score was 10, normal is in the range of 241-827. How long does it take to recover testosterone production?? Since hormone therapy is really chemical castration, I have no thoughts of ever scoring in the normal range ever again. However, I would hopefully like to produce something far more then a "10," to improve libido, energy, and stamina. I also would like to know how long Eligard remains in my system?? This all follows a RP, and 38 sessions of adjuvent radiation. Good news, is that I have been in the zero club for last 16 months. Thanks for any advise!
Posts.Title: Recovery from Eligard/Lupron hormone therapy??

Posts.Content: The Publication Medscape has the following article: https://www.medscape.com/viewarticle...l&uac=279903DJ. I am taking venlafaxine for hot flashes, and can say it definitely helps. It is an antidepressant, so it also helps in that regard.

Posts.Content: Hi Felix, I have had two recent cystoscopys done within the past 3 weeks. My situation is a bit different, in that I am recovering from DaVinci Rp, and I have a problem where the urethra is reattached to the bladder. For unknown reasons, I have a great deal of pain for the past 3-4 weeks. So my surgeon said he needed to "take a look," The instrument is a flexible cable like devise that is inserted into your Johnson, and moved up, and into the bladder. In my case, I had a lot of inflammation, so probably helped to produced extra pain, even though a little pain killer gel was inserted into the tip of my Johnson. 10 days ago, I had another cystoscopy done in his office. This time I showed up at his office after having taken 2 codeine based pain pills. This time the pain was more bearable at about a 4 level, not like the 7-or 8 level as before. I see my doc on Thursday. I don't know what he wants to do, but I will take a couple of pain pills as before to mediate any pain. If the procedure is done in his office, chances are it will be with the local pain killer only. I can say that urination afterwards was normal with no pain, so don't have much concern about that.

Posts.Content: For years, I have been purchasing Sildenafil (generic Viagra) 100mg. Cost is $75 for 48 pills from a pharmacy in Canada with free shipping. That works out to $1.56/pill. I don't need the strength of 100 mg., so I use a pill splitter to break up the pill into pieces. This process reduces the cost per dosage considerably. Results are just as good as Viagra. Purchasing is very easy. Just have your doctor fax the prescription scrip to the pharmacy, and pay for it by credit card. Pills delivered to your door. I purchase from Pharmacy RX world, located in Toronto. Their website is: https://www.pharmacyrxworld.com I highly recommend them. Their customer service is excellent. There are many pharmacys in Canada selling to Americans. Easy to find with a Google search.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 Rooster: You may not need anything. If u do, Vaseline jelly works just as well. U don't need a applicator, a q-tip will work just fine. U r just putting it around where the catheter is inserted in your penis. BTW...half the stuff they told me I needed I never used. The 3 most important things are baggy shorts/ sweats, a nice recliner, and depends. (Extra absorbent) Don't waste your money running around buying all the crap they tell u. Buy it as needed. U may not need any type of ointment, rubber gloves, wipes, blah, blah, blah. Since it is summer, get some baggy shorts, hang the bag in your pocket, and pee away!! Use the big bag so u don't have to change it often. Get a long cord with the bag ( hospital provided) and u can sleep in your bed. Keep the bag below u. Best Wishes, MM Thanks, appreciate all the advise, especially regarding the long cord. I have a recliner, but can't use for several reasons. I have added an extra mattress to my bed, so it sits really high now. Should be okay to enter and exit bed. Today bought some walking shorts with elastic waist band about 1-2 size larger then needed. Shorts also have a string tie, if needed. Should work well. I like the idea of using the Q tip, yea that should work okay. I know very little about the catheter maintenance. Guess that education comes from a nurse at the hospital. I am creative enough to figure out some of the catheter usage on my own. Already bought the depends and liners. Guess I have that covered. Thanks for the good advise............Larry..............Rooster2

Posts.Content: I developed an Incisional hernia, known as a Ventral hernia after RALP. My RALP was a year ago. Apparently a ventral hernia is common after pelvic surgery. It developed right at the sight of the incision, and presented itself as a tummy bulge. It was there, that the muscle tore open at the scar, with the bowel trying to push itself through the muscle tear. I think that my bout of heavy coughing from bronchitis may have caused the problem. The hernia was easily fixed with Laparoscopic repair, just 3 hole portals in my abdomen with plastic mesh installed through the portals to give the muscle extra strength. Not much pain involved after out patient surgery, just soreness for the past few days. I just think it is important enough for anyone who has had a RALP, or open surgery to be aware of a potential hernia problem developing. Any unusual tummy bulge that shows up should be checked out by a physician.
Posts.Title: Incisional hernia developed after RALP

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Consult1 Thanks for the head's up! Glad that you had it taken care of. Did your doctor find it on a scheduled visit? Yes, had my 3 month check up with uro/surgeon. I asked him what the lump on my stomach was. I just never thought it could be a hernia. It was a surprise.
Posts.Title: Incisional hernia developed after RALP

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rmotacek1 Rooster-thanks for this info. I have been wondering if I might need to go get checked. I have some minor pain at my largest incision scar above my navel and when I cough hard it bulges out a little but goes back in. That is the same exact location of my hernia, just above the naval, where the surgery scar is located. I had a puffy bulge upon standing, but would disappear when lying flat on my back. The hernia started to bother me with some burning pain with any physical work, so I knew it was time to have it looked at by a doc. Doc said it would probably tear larger over time, so it was time to get it repaired. I still can't believe how easy recovery was after Laparoscopic surgery. Very minimal pain right after surgery, with minimal soreness for just 2 days. I had surgery at 10 AM, and was home by 12:30 PM, and immediately was able to walk our two dogs. I had no lifting restrictions, and was bowling 7 days after surgery. Laparoscopic surgery is a true blessing over what was done previously with open surgery.
Posts.Title: Incisional hernia developed after RALP

Posts.Content: Email from a friend, hope report is true, that NASA astronaut, CAPT Scott "Maker" Tingle, who once was diagnosed with prostate cancer with a PSA of 201 is at this very moment conducting a space walk to perform maintenance on the International Space Station. We seem to have more and more options every week. With any luck ours will be the first generation in which men don't have to die of prostate cancer, and the last generation that were left with choices of surgery, or radiation as the price for survival. Here is the latest development. Unfortunately, it doesn't seem to be in widespread clinical use just yet. It is worth a read........ http://www.nymox.com/default.action?itemid=23 or click HERE.
Posts.Title: Astronaut survives prostate cancer

Posts.Content: My treatment for Pca has progressed much like yours, with a gleason score of 7. I had Pca in seminal vessels, but none detected in lymph nodes, though doctor thought otherwise. I had 8 weeks of radiation Had RP, three months later had psa of 2.1, month later psa 2.2. So doctor started on Eligard hormone thereapy injections, which is the same stuff as firmagon, just a different name brand. I am now 17 months on Eligard, and still doing the hot flashes. I, too, gave strong thought of bailing out of HT, but then read on line the significant statistical increase of not getting biological occurrence of PCA, when HT is given for 18 to 24 months. The reasoning is that HT does not kill any remaining Pca cells, but causes a huge testosterone reduction, which causes Pca cells to go into hibernation, not replicate, and turn old and die off. With that information, I decided to continue on HT for the best chance of a cure. My doc says I have an 80% chance of a cure. If Pca does reoccur, doc says I will be on hormone therapy for the rest of my life. At present my psa is undectible. My advise is go the long route of HT, though it is not easy, but do-able. It gives you that much better of a chance for a cure. There is a med I take to reduces number of hot flashes, and there intensity. I will discuss if you are interested.
Posts.Title: Looking for opinion

Posts.Content: The med I take to reduce hot flashes is Venlafaxine ER 37.5 mg capsule. I think that is a generic named product, but not sure. The product is actually a med to combat depression. I recently had an annual physical with my family doctor. I told him my HT has affected my temperament, in that I have reduced patience in dealing with people. I have to watch myself to not verbally snap at my wife over trivial problems. My doc thinks that is a symptom of depression, so he increased Venlafaxine to 75 mg strength. I am glad to say that it is helping me. I feel less intense. Control of hot flashes remains the same. Suggest you do a google search of side effects of Eligard, Lupron, and firmagon. I think all three are the same, just different manufacturers. There are probably a dozen side effects to the med. It is important to know what they are, should you continue on HT, and be prepared to deal with them. One of the most important things is to take calcium, with vitamin D to combat bone loss while on HT. It is also important to get lots of exercise to keep your muscle strength up, and to feel better about yourself. As said in my last post, HT is not easy, but do-able. Far better to be on HT now, with a better chance of gaining a cure, then to have biological occurrence, and therefore relegated to hormone therapy for the rest of your life. I keep thinking that all forms of prostate cancer treatment is crude and barbaric, and wish all cancer patients could live their lives 50 years in the future. Treatment most certainly will be so much better by then. For now, all we can do, is complete the treatments offered to us, and hope and pray for the best.

Posts.Title: Looking for opinion

Posts.Content: My treatment for Pca has progressed much like yours, with a gleason score of 7. I had Pca in seminal vessels, but none detected in lymph nodes, though doctor thought otherwise. I had 8 weeks of radiation Had RP, three months later had psa of 2.1, month later psa 2.2. So doctor started on Eligard hormone thereapy injections, which is the same stuff as firmagon, just a different name brand. I am now 17 months on Eligard, and still doing the hot flashes. I, too, gave strong thought of bailing out of HT, but then read on line the significant statistical increase of not getting biological occurrence of PCA, when HT is given for 18 to 24 months. The reasoning is that HT does not kill any remaining Pca cells, but causes a huge testosterone reduction, which causes Pca cells to go into hibernation, not replicate, and turn old and die off. With that information, I decided to continue on HT for the best chance of a cure. My doc says I have an 80% chance of a cure. If Pca does reoccur, doc says I will be on hormone therapy for the rest of my life. At present my psa is undectible. My advise is go the long route of HT, though it is not easy, but do-able. It gives you that much better of a chance for a cure. There is a med I take to reduces number of hot flashes, and there intensity. I will discuss if you are interested.

Posts.Title: RP questions

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee When you say stage 3, I assume you mean you were either T3a or T3b. Hopefully the eight weeks of radiation cleaned up whatever cancer may have remained following your RP. That's what it was supposed to do anyway, not necessarily the Eligard. The HT is intended to keep your PSA down between RP and SRT (or at least, that's how I understand it's supposed to work). Also tenderize the cancer cells so to speak.. it starves them of that tasty testosterone they love so much. It's a bit disappointing that some of the more knowledgeable guys haven't replied yet. Hopefully they will soon. If you could provide your exact pathology... margins, LNI, SVI or whatever, that might help. I have never seen a pathology report. My surgeon urologist is not very communicative, which I don't like. Last week I got a second opinion from another urologist. Best investment of time and $40 copay ever. Learned my status is PT3B, with probable positive margins, since PCa escaped from the capsule. Since I just completed adjuvent radiation, while on Eligard, and projected another 18 months on Eligard by my doc, it is, impossible to tell if the radiation killed off remaining PC cells. Last blood test showed psa <.0l, so Eligard is working well for me. At this rate, it will be another 18 months to see if psa rises without Eligard, to judge effectiveness of RT Second opinion doctor advised using Eligard for just a year per latest research. Guess, I could go this route, and if psa starts rising, then it is back on Eligard, and I would know that RT did not leave me cancer free. I may switch my care to the second opinion doctor beginning the first of the year. I have to wait until then, as my current Medicare supplement has second opinion doc as "out of network." Currently having problems from the radiation. It burns to take a leak, and has been this way for about 2 weeks. I gave a urine sample at a lab for testing for infection, but feel sure that the radiation is the cause. I hope to hear back from radiation oncologist soon, and what can be done. Hope this condition is short lived. Nothing is easy in the treatment of PCa.

Posts.Content: Guess, I am one of the lucky ones when it comes to incontinence control. After RALP, my surgeon said I had a well developed sphincter muscle on re-attachment, when many men don't. After that really no problems, with the exception of mild dribbles, if I have an urgent bowel movement coming on, or try to expel a fart. No problem when sneezing or coughing. Sometimes, a tiny squirt, if I let my bladder get too full.

Posts.Content: Yes, it is possible to have a secondary cancer. A friend of mine had prostate cancer, and bladder cancer at the same time. The two cancers were not related to one another, just separate cancers. He has been fortunate to have both cared for, with no further problems from either one. I am sure the "something in your throat" will be diagnosed fully, so you will learn exactly what it is, and how to deal with it. Hope all goes well, God bless.
Posts.Title: Prostate cancer low PSA

Posts.Content: As others have posted, you should discuss these problems with the radiation doctor. I had 8 weeks of radiation, 5 days a week, and saw my radiation doctor once a week for discussion and updates. I am guessing this is standard practice, so there is your opportunity to speak with your doctor, now, or within a week. I had the rectal balloon installed before each treatment to move a good portion of the bowel out of the way of the radiation. I think it helped. Some doctors subscribe to the balloon others don't. In your case, it may help. Your one injection in abdomen that is supposed to be good for 6 months is most likely Eligard hormone therapy. That is being given to help make radiation treatment more effective in treatment of cancer cells. Suggest you do a google search of Eligard to learn about its side effects, should you experience some. Most common side effect is hot flashes. Another side effect is increased depletion of calcium from the bone. I take calcium/vitamin D pills to counteract the problem. You may want to do this as well. Hang in there with your radiation. I know it becomes a drag, and comes to feel like a part time job. However, the days and weeks pass quickly, and then you are done with it. Good luck, and God bless.

Posts.Title: Decimal point in PSA level

Posts.Content: Like you are having, I started on Eligard (same stuff as Lupron, just different manufacturer) two months before 38 IMRT treatments. Yes, the Lupron does increase the effectiveness of radiation treatments. Lupron suppresses testosterone growth, the hormone which fuels the growth of prostate cancer cells. It does not kill Pca cells, but puts them into hibernation, so they don't replicate, and with time will die off like all other cells do. It is also thought that the lack of testosterone weakens the pca cells, so radiation therapy is more effective. Lupron/Eligard is continued for as long as 2-3 years, hoping the lack of testosterone will find pca cells that may be elsewhere in the body, and help them die off with out replicating during the 2-3 year period. I completed 19 months of Eligard. The side effects were not pleasant, but do-able. Quality of life was not that much disrupted. I think it has been well worthwhile treatment. I have an 80% chance of a cure, lower then that without Eligard. If your cancer has not spread outside the prostate gland, then your time on Lupron will be much less then mine.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by PDV Rooster, one thing I and many others have found is that, post op, when you have to go, you really have to go. Without that second brake Chuck mentioned, the feeling of urgency can be acute and you need to take care of it ASAP. I peed the bed once in the first month. I had a hard time with the pads chaffing my junk so I didn't use them at all after three weeks but I did answer every call to pee urgently. The only time I peed the bed again was when I took an Adavan to help me sleep three months post op and slept through my bladder's wake up call. That being said, I believe the majority of guys return to full continence. In my case it was relatively quickly, other than pee coming out during orgasm. That took a half year or so to stop. My surgeon said he was able to spare a good urethra stem and predicted incontinence would resolve quickly and it did. Good luck. I can really get a sense of the second brake missing. It feels like urinary control is now located only at the base of my penis. Now when I urinate, the flow seems to drop straight down about 10 inches in a hurry from the bladder with a high degree of force for expulsion. The first time I peed with a rather full bladder, it surprised me how fast and forceful the urine stream was. I can't remember emptying my bladder so fast. I now fell qualified to put out small forest fires in California at a moments notice. So far my bladder control is not bad, mostly just some squirts at odd times. I remain continent sleeping at night, getting maybe once or twice at night to hit the john. Yes, I do now pay attention to urgency to relieve myself. If I feel a need to go, then it is time to go NOW. If I wait, I will beginning squirting. Thanks for all the great advise and encouragement.

Posts.Title: Now I'm even more nervous

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Your incontinence is a classically standard sign of a normal recovery. With many, it takes considerable time for full continence to return. As for the plumbing... In the "factory manufactured" male urination plumbing arrangement, there are three "brakes" that control urine. As we are born, we are equipped with the sphincter muscle where the bladder is connected to the urethra. That is the first brake that helps provide continence and control urine flow. The second brake is the prostate, itself, since the urethra goes through the center of the prostate. The third one is the sphincter muscle at the base of the penis where the urethra emerges from the bottom of the prostate. If I'm not mistaken (hopefully I don't have this backwards), the sphincter at the base of the bladder is called the "internal" one and the one at the base of the penis is the "external" one. During a standard prostatectomy, the prostate removal, of course, removes one of those brakes. Usually, the sphincter at the top of the prostate (where it connects to the bladder) is also removed. As a result, the patient is left with only the one sphincter, at the base of the penis, to hold urine back and also control its flow. This is in conjunction with the urethra being reattached to the bladder (the bladder is gently moved downward to fill the gap where the prostate once lived) without the bladder sphincter that was removed during the surgery. Basically, the female plumbing system comes from the "factory" with only that one sphincter -- the same one that males are left with after surgery. So, in effect, a man is no worse off than a female after going through the surgery. It also shows why many females must do the Kegel exercises after giving birth, etc. This muscle, by nature, is not a very strong muscle, though, and too many Kegel reps can tend to weaken it. So it is important to not overdo the Kegel exercises. In fact, Mayo Clinic advises prostatectomy patients to do only a total of 7 (just seven individual squeezings) per day -- and to do them most every day for life. Hope this helps a bit. Thanks Highlander, I can tell you know what you are talking about. Your medical knowledge, and discussion helps me understand continence problems a lot better now.
Posts.Title: Incontitent discussion w/MD

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bernard1 Rooster, I'm 4 weeks post DaVinci. Like many on this forum, my continence is a lot better in the morning and then deteriorates in the late afternoon/evening. I even have great days and not so great days. I'm going through 2-3 pull ups a day (I call them 'man wraps') because I'm still too freaked out to go with just pads. While all of this is frustrating, I know its most likely temporary and I continue to focus on the fact that the cancerous prostate is long gone! After reading the sticky post about the Mayo kegel regimen, I've been following that process. All the best to you! Agree that the Mayo Kegel advise is good. Like you, I am continent during the day, but after dinner I am getting tired, and start loosing the conscientious effort to tighten up the floor muscle to control continent. Then next, I find myself squiring unexpectedly. I have learned to immediately go to the bathroom to relieve myself. It surprises me that I can pee quite a lot, and have no sense that my bladder is getting full. Seems like loosing the prostate diminishes the feeling of the bladder filling up. Don't know if I need to get used to this happening, or with healing some sense of how full the bladder is becoming will return to my brain. Like you, not proud to be wearing "pull ups," but that is the new reality for a while or longer. Just need to have a mind adjustment to get used to the new reality. Like you, glad the prostate is history. Good luck to your continued recovery.

Posts.Title: Hot flash treatments

Posts.Content: Sudds, I had similar problem after prostate surgery. The doctor will probably want to a cystoscopy "take a look," to see if there is some obstruction in the urethra, and or the bladder. That means a flexible cable is inserted into your johnson, and pushed up into your bladder. When that was done, it hurt like hell. Having the nurse put a cold wet paper towel on my forehead did little to ease the pain. Doc did not find any obstruction in my case, but had to go back 2 weeks later for "another look see. "Upon my return, I prepared myself by taking a couple of the oxy pain pills remaining from surgery about an hour before my appointment. That made the procedure much more bearable. I never told my doc that I took the med, as he was totally oblivious to the amount of pain I was enduring. There are times that you just have to look out for yourself. Some docs just don't care how much pain they inflict.
Posts.Title: It hurts bad when I Urinate

Posts.Content: I had the balloon after a protatectomy. It was highly recommended by my radiation oncologist. I am glad I had it. I will never know how much it helped to move a portion of the rectum out of the way from radiation, but I can say I had no rectal problems after radiation. It is a little uncomfortable having the balloon devise installed, but once installed, it is not uncomfortable at all. As others have said, it is important to gain as much continence as possible before radiation, as I was told, and others have said, that radiation stops any further improvement in continence control. In my case, I slid back a little bit in continence control, but I can live with little dribble drops once in a while, and an occasional minor squirt upon sneezing or coughing. Often hormone therapy is started a month or two prior to radiation. That is what my doctor did for me. There is evidence that hormone therapy "softens up" prostate cancer cells, so that the radiation is more effective in treating the pc cells. Also, hormone therapy is known to put pc cells into hibernation, so they don't divide and spread. This hibernation period also gives you time to work on your keegles to improve continence. You don't have to rush into radiation. It was 6 months post surgery, that I started my 8 weeks of radiation. Plenty of time to get my continence under control. Lastly, be aware that small radiation treatment centers, often in small towns, do not have the latest and greatest radiation equipment, as most often found in large metro hospitals. Older equipment is just not as good as newer equipment. The control of the radiation beam is not as good. A friend of mine has a job of calibrating cancer radiation equipment. His advise to me was to find a radiation department that uses the Varian rapid arc equipment, not the older equipment that radiates on a herky jerky stop and go zapping basis. That is what I did, and am glad I followed his advise. Good luck to you. Ask us more questions, we are glad to help you. Don't be intimidated about asking your doctor as much as possible. After all, it is your health, and life that is on the line, not his or hers.
Posts.Title: Radiation starting soon, what is best way to protect other parts

Posts.Content: Seems like everyone reacts differently from radiation treatments. I had 39 treatments, and had no problems until the last week, when I developed burning pain during urination. This continued to get even worse after completion of radiation. Both the radiation MD, and my urology doctor thought I had developed blockage in my urethra and bladder. I had out patient surgery to correct this supposed problem, but surgeon found nothing wrong. Urologist had me drinking lots of water, and taking meds that turned my urine orange. The "orange" drug did not help. At this point the pain was really bad, and lasted for several months until doctor said to take 2 Aleve in the morning, and 2 Aleve in the evening. This was a far higher dose then what is prescribed on the med bottle. However, this worked and cured my problem within 3 days of taking Aleve. I stopped taking Aleve after one week because of my concern regarding potential damage to my liver or kidneys. I have had no problems since. I, and my urologist finally concluded my urethra was "cooked" from the radiation. As stated, everyone responds different to radiation. I hope your problem quiets down. Suggest drinking plenty of water to keep flushing out your system. This dilutes your urine, and decrease the burning pain urination. Take care, I hope it gets better for you.
Posts.Title: starting to feel the burn

Posts.Content: Had a couple of discussions regarding incontinence before and after my Da Vinci. Dr. told me that my BPH (enlarged prostate) was pressing on my urethra. This causes the slower stream of urine, but the restriction also helps towards continence. Over time your body gets use to the BPH restriction, and as a result the muscles don't have to work so hard to contain the urine, and are happy to be weak and lazy. I don't think I had ever read about this anywhere on this forum. Now removing the prostate is a game changer, it is off to do Kegel exercises to strengthen those weak muscles. The doctor may have also said something else about the prostate having another bladder control feature, but I can't remember any specifics. If so, with removal that feature is gone too. In my case, I am 13 days post Da Vinci. I am having some trouble staying dry. If I sneeze, or cough, or pass gas, I will squirt urine in a hurry. I am learning to tighten up muscles before these things happen. I also am not continent when I am tired, or not feeling well with a head ache. Discussion after surgery, my surgeon said that I have a longer then usual tube extending from the bottom of the bladder, and that it is more muscular then normal. So, he said I should not have much difficulty getting continent. Well, I am sticking with the Kegels, still it is a small inconvenient price to pay for getting rid of a cancerous prostate. The Da Vinci surgery is a blessing.
Posts.Title: Incontitent discussion w/MD

Posts.Content: I had the balloon after a protatectomy. It was highly recommended by my radiation oncologist. I am glad I had it. I will never know how much it helped to move a portion of the rectum out of the way from radiation, but I can say I had no rectal problems after radiation. It is a little uncomfortable having the balloon devise installed, but once installed, it is not uncomfortable at all. As others have said, it is important to gain as much continence as possible before radiation, as I was told, and others have said, that radiation stops any further improvement in continence control. In my case, I slid back a little bit in continence control, but I can live with little dribble drops once in a while, and an occasional minor squirt upon sneezing or coughing. Often hormone therapy is started a month or two prior to radiation. That is what my doctor did for me. There is evidence that hormone therapy "softens up" prostate cancer cells, so that the radiation is more effective in treating the pc cells. Also, hormone therapy is known to put pc cells into hibernation, so they don't divide and spread. This hibernation period also gives you time to work on your keegles to improve continence. You don't have to rush into radiation. It was 6 months post surgery, that I started my 8 weeks of radiation. Plenty of time to get my continence under control. Lastly, be aware that small radiation treatment centers, often in small towns, do not have the latest and greatest radiation equipment, as most often found in large metro hospitals. Older equipment is just not as good as newer equipment. The control of the radiation beam is not as good. A friend of mine has a job of calibrating cancer radiation equipment. His advise to me was to find a radiation department that uses the Varian rapid arc equipment, not the older equipment that radiates on a herky jerky stop and go zapping basis. That is what I did, and am glad I followed his advise. Good luck to you. Ask us more questions, we are glad to help you. Don't be intimidated about asking your doctor as much as possible. After all, it is your health, and life that is on the line, not his or hers.
Posts.Title: Radiation starting soon, what is best way to protect other parts

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 Hello Rooster. For high risk cases, pT3b such as yourself, they do know that 2 years are better than 6 months. That has been shown in various studies. The question is what happens between the 6 month mark and extending out for a few years. There are so many different views that I will relate to you what my MO told me. He likened it to not taking antibiotics for the entire course. They would not be as effective. He also pointed me to the study in the following link.https://www.astro.org/uploadedFiles/...1580_FINAL.pdf As with all things PCa, one can get a lot of different answers. However, all of my Doctors, MO, Ro, Uro, etc have insisted on 2 years in my case. I believe they called this the DART study. Good Luck, MM Thanks MM16, the info you have provided is very helpful. I appreciate that.
Posts.Title: How long should I be on ADT (hormone therapy)?

Posts.Content: I don't have the data to list my med bio info as most others have done. Do know that I am a Gleason 7, and classed as PT3B. I had RALP last August, followed by 8 weeks of External Beam Radiation, that was completed in mid April. Prior to radiation I started Eligard. I am now at 8 months on Eligard, and doc says I need to be on ADT for 2 years. That scares me, as RO told me that 2 years on Eligard may only give me about 20% testosterone recovery forever. I know I am at "high risk," and I guess/think that means a high risk of biological occurrence over time. Well, I know my surgeon urologist has thrown about every tool he has available as treatment, ie surgery, radiation, and ADT. My complaint with him is that he is so non communicative. It is difficult to get questions answered in depth. He will not give reasoning as to why he thinks 2 years is needed. Because of this communication problem, I got a second opinion from another urologist, who advised me that being on ADT for 1 year is sufficient. My dilemma is who's advise should I take. No one wants to be on ADT one day more then needed, and yet I want to give myself the best opportunity of beating the ca monster. I understand that ADT puts cancer cells into hibernation, so they don't reproduce, and die off from old age. My last PSA was .003, so Eligard, and radiation are serving me well. However, I don't understand the reasoning of extended use in my case to two years on Eligard. What advantage is there being on Eligard for 2 years verses 1 year? I could not find an answer to this question anywhere on the internet. Thanks for any advise. I appreciate the existence of this forum, and to those who care enough to take the time to post solid advise. Regards, Rooster2

Posts.Content: I am 5 weeks post DaVinci, and all is well, except trouble I think with the sphincter urethrae. Before surgery I did a good number of keegles, but after surgery, the sphincter was too sore to do keegles, and has continued to be too sore to do keegles. Fortunately, I have not had trouble regaining continence, but the soreness continues at the sphincter. It is made much worse after a normal, not hard, bowel movement. That activity really irritates the sphincter to the point that it aches severely with time. I now have to apply an ice pack to control the pain. It seems like I have swelling at the site, so passing urine is becoming more difficult. Seems like I have to push and squeeze the urine out. Anyone experience this problem?? I see my uro surgeon tomorrow for a 5-6 week check up and blood test. This problem will be at the top of my list of what to do. Thanks for any advise.

Posts.Content: I am starting to think the same thing.........an infection.

Still pissing okay, so it hasn't reached an emergency situation yet. This has come about after surgery. First a pinched nerve in my shoulder, which produced much pain for 2 weeks, making it hard to sleep, followed by an inner ear infection with much pain that lasted for 10 days, am just getting over that. Posts.Title: Radiation question

Posts.Content: Having had the DaVinci radical prostatectomy, I learned that when the prostate is removed, the urethra tube (piss tube) is cut and pulled up causing the penis to shorten a little, and the flexible bladder is distended down to meet the shortened urethera, and permanently sutured in place. The urethra is reattached to the bladder to fill the void left by the missing prostate. The bladder now holds less urine when full in its new location. This is not so noticeable during the day, but reduced capacity has me getting up several times during the night to pee. A few times, I wake up to leakage. Suggest you drink less liquid in the evening to see if that helps your situation. The new normal after prostatectomy has its draw backs. Hope this info helps you to understand your revised anatomy.

Posts.Content: Pottk..Your profile is exactly the same as mine. After surgery, 3 months later, my psa was 2.1, next month, it was 2.2. Doc immediately started me on hormone therapy. I had a bad side effect from surgery that kept me from radiation treatment for 4 months. All the while, I continued on hormone therapy, then completed 8 weeks of radiation of the prostate bed. I have now completed 16 months of hormone therapy, and may go 19-24 months total. The hormone therapy has knocked down my psa to undetectable for many months now, My urologist said that I have had all the available treatments available, and have an 80% chance of a cure. I would not be surprised if your future treatment becomes the same, or similar to mine. Hang in there we can both beat this cancer.
Posts.Title: Not good news

Posts.Title: get a rating of surgeons in your area

Posts.Content: Welcome to the forum. Everyone here is trying to be helpful. I well understand your confusion as how to proceed with treatment. I had the same problem last year. My urologist recommended either RALP or radiation. With no medical background it seems crazy to make a serious medical decision effecting your life. The surgeon will recommend surgery, the radiation group will recommend external beam radiation, so you are still left on your own. Suggest you read the stick notes at the start of this forum regarding radiation and surgery from those who have been there. The down side of both is that they will heavily impact your sex life negatively. You may want to look into brachytherapy as a possibility. I know several guys, who have had great results with brachy, and have been able to keep their sex lives. Brachytherapy also has a sticky note section, check it out.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed

Posts.Content: Frequently hormone therapy (ADT) is begun before radiation. The ADT adversely affects Ca cells, so radiation is more effective. I had 38 sessions of radiation. My RO ordered a rectal balloon insertion before each radiation session. It helps to move a portion of the colon out of the path of radiation. Which is a good thing. Not all radiologists prescribe the balloon, but I am glad mine did. It was not painful to have it inserted, just somewhat uncomfortable when inserted. Once inserted, it cannot be felt.

Posts.Title: What side effects and results experienced from Xofigo?

Posts.Content: A support group based in Canada has excellent information for those on ADT. They offer a book, as well as offer a webinar program. I joined their webinar educational program presentation via the "go to meeting" format last Wednesday. It was an excellent hour and a half program detailing the effects, and side effects of ADT with things I did not know, like ADT can be the cause of emotional irritability. I also learned that being on ADT for a 2 years, then stopping treatment, it will take a year for Leigard/Lupron to leave your body. Also, at that point, your body may only recover the ability to produce at a 20% testosterone level, that it produced prior to ADT. The Canadian group can be found by Googling "Life on ADT," or http://www.lifeonadt.com/ I highly recommend joining their educational presentation via "go to meeting." They ask that both you and your partner attend the webinar meeting together.
Posts.Title: Those on hormone therapy (ADT) may want to learn more about ADT

Posts.Content: Had the Foley removed 7 days after RP. Once removed, I did not have much of a problem with incontinence. Wore a diaper or pad for just a few days, maybe a week, not much more. I still squirt a little upon sneezing or coughing, but so minimal that I don't wear a pad. I never did much in the way of Keegle exercises, just didn't seem to need it. I have had no problems with urethra pain or penis pain from RP. Seems like I have had plenty of warning when time to take a leak. Just seems like my bladder is smaller, so have to go pee more often.
Posts.Title: Post RP incontinence survey

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee Yeah, just ask my wife about that one! The info on T recovery was never presented to me before the first shot... not until the third. I'm looking forward to viewing that webcast. Thanks for the heads up! The only side effect my uro/surgeon told me about Eligard, was that I could develop hot flashes. That was it. It was only after doing web research, and attending the webinar, that I learned about growing belly fat, man boobs, loosing hair on legs and chest, loss of bone, and muscle, emotional problems, and my balance on two feet is off. Thank God, I only have 3 more months on Eligard, but then have to wait nearly a year for Eligard to clear from my system. Looking at the big picture, I realize the need for Eligard to help me make a cure after surgery, and 8 weeks of radiation. However, enough is enough, I would like to get back to a better quality of life.

Posts.Title: Post RP incontinence survey

Posts.Content: Keep up the low psa scores. They are just what you want to see. I had an incisional hernia after RALP. It is not uncommon. I decided to have it repaired, as I felt it could only get worse, though it was not bothering me. The surgery was done as out patient under general anesthesia via arthroscopic. Just three hoses in my abdomen were used to install plastic mesh. It has to be my easiest surgery ever. Really hardly any pain, registered about a 1 or a 2 pain level. Went home put an ice pack on my abdomen, and went to sleep. The next day just minimal soreness, The second day I felt good as new. Really did not need the narcotic pain pills. Quickly went to Tylenol. My surgeon urologist referred me to a general surgeon for the hernia repair. I asked the doc before surgery if I could get a copy of the surgery video. He said he doesn't video, but would get me pictures of the surgery. At out patient departure, I was given 4 still pictures of my surgery in color. All were pictures of the mess insertion inside my abdomen. Pretty interesting how the mesh is "tacked" into place with tiny rivets. They dissolve away in about 9 months, during which time scar tissue grows in and around the mesh to hold it in place. If you do the surgery, find a doc who will do the surgery arthroscopically, much easier recovery then having it done by the open surgery method.
Posts.Title: 7.5 months post RALP

Posts.Content: I, too, developed an incision hernia post RALP. I had it repaired laparoscopically as out patient surgery. It was an unbelievably easy surgery, had minimal pain, used an ice pack only for one day. On day two, I felt really good, was back to doing anything I wanted. Used pain pills first day only, aspirin for another day afterwards. Advise getting hernia repaired. It won't get any better left along, only potentially worse.

Posts.Content: Suggest if you haven't done so, read the sticky note thread near the top of this web page. Here is a link to it: https://www.cancerforums.net/threads...-Vinci-surgery Gots lots of good advise there. Giood luck, You will do just fine. Rooster22
Posts.Title: RP Exactly One Week From Today - Any Last Minute Advice?

Posts.Content: Won't ever know if bowling at 4 weeks caused the problem. My surgeon said ok to bowl after 4 weeks, so I went ahead and bowled. I never felt any pain, or discomfort during, or after bowling, so just don't know. Life is now much better with catheter in. All the severe crotch pain is gone, along with the burning pain upon urination. What a relief that is. This Foley catheter is somewhat different from the one installed at time of surgery. Just what the difference is, I am not sure, but it is really not noticeable 90% of the time. Just so much more comfortable using this catheter. I just have to watch how full the travel bag is during the day. I nearly over filled it. I make it a point to lube the penis tip several times during the day, so it does not get irritated as it did with the Foley installed at time of surgery. So far, so good. Thanks for the words of encouragement. I appreciate that.

Posts.Title: 2 months after DaVinci, back on Foley catheter again

Posts.Content: Had posted earlier about development of much pain that seemed to get worse beginning at week 5. At week 6, saw my surgeon who said the problem lie with the rejoining of the urethra to the bladder. My rejoining developed a problem for reasons unknown. He said to take it easy, and it should get better on its own. Well it did not, and after struggling with the burning pain for 2 weeks, I met again with my surgeon yesterday. He put me back on a Foley catheter for 2 weeks, and said things should heal. Two of the physician's assistants said that my problem just sometimes happens, and weren't surprised that I was still encountering the problem 8 weeks post surgery. They had treated a number of patients with the same problem. Both assistants said I will fully recover with some time to heal. The doc did another cystocopy on me before inserting the catheter. From having my first cystocopy two weeks prior, I was not looking forward to the procedure again with pain level 7 intensity. That was torture. This time on my own, I took 2 codeine based pain pills just prior to going to his office to curb the pain. I was glad I did, as pain level intensity dropped to a tolerable 4 level. It just seems to me that uro doctors don't have a great concern for patient pain for procedures done in their office. Just my humble opinion.
Posts.Title: 2 months after DaVinci, back on Foley catheter again

Posts.Content: I kept getting a psa test with yearly physicals. My family doc said my rising psa was from benign prostate enlargement, and not to be concerned with it. At age 71, psa had risen to 7.4, so referred me to see a urologist. Only then did I get the treatment that I really needed. Unfortunately, cancer has escaped the prostate to have me at stage 3. Family doc should have caught my problem much earlier. So, yes testing after age 70 is important. Not having done so, would have me fast tracking to stage 4, and I still have a chance of going stage 4.

Posts.Content: Update.............met with my uro surgeon who did my Da Vinci. My pain problem has been diagnosed as problem with a suture used to reconnect the urethra to the bladder. Somehow, the suture rubs on tissue as I walk or move about. This causes irritation, which causes inflammation, which causes burning pain to erupt. My catheter was removed today after 13 days of usage. Glad to say good-bye to that medical devise. Only solution is to bear the pain, and with time things should get better. The only option is open surgery, which doc says that would leave me incontinent. Doc said I am the first patient he has had to develop this problem, though he has heard from other surgeons with patients who have had this problem. So surgery is not realistic as a way to fix the pain problem. I will just have to bite the bullet and endure the pain. He gave me a prescription for Celebrex, as well as Percocet. Still an ice pack for my crotch may be my best friend for a while. I am frustrated, but things bound to get better.
Posts.Title: 2 months after DaVinci, back on Foley catheter again

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee There are two types of sutures, dissolving and permanent. Typically permanent suture is black and temporary is clear, like fishing line. They use permanent suture for heart surgery (valves and such). Dissolving suture is used for most other applications. I don't know which would be used for the urethra bladder union. Eventually scar tissue grows over the sutures. Thanks Roblee for the info. I am surmising the suture joining urethra to bladder is a permanent suture, or else it would have dissolved after 10 weeks. Doc says give it more time to heal, which prolly means scar tissue will grow over the suture to complete the heal. My doc really doesn't want to spend the time to explain things in detail to me. By the time, I think of a question like this, I am already gone from his office.

Posts.Title: 2 months after DaVinci, back on Foley catheter again

Posts.Content: Had posted earlier about development of much pain that seemed to get worse beginning at week 5. At week 6, saw my surgeon who said the problem lie with the rejoining of the urethra to the bladder. My rejoining developed a problem for reasons unknown. He said to take it easy, and it should get better on its own. Well it did not, and after struggling with the burning pain for 2 weeks, I met again with my surgeon yesterday. He put me back on a Foley catheter for 2 weeks, and said things should heal. Two of the physician's assistants said that my problem just sometimes happens, and weren't surprised that I was still encountering the problem 8 weeks post surgery. They had treated a number of patients with the same problem. Both assistants said I will fully recover with some time to heal. The doc did another cystocopy on me before inserting the catheter. From having my first cystocopy two weeks prior, I was not looking forward to the procedure again with pain level 7 intensity. That was torture. This time on my own, I took 2 codeine based pain pills just prior to going to his office to curb the pain. I was glad I did, as pain level intensity dropped to a tolerable 4 level. It just seems to me that uro doctors don't have a great concern for patient pain for procedures done in their office. Just my humble opinion.

Posts.Title: 2 months after DaVinci, back on Foley catheter again

Posts.Content: Won't ever know if bowling at 4 weeks caused the problem. My surgeon said ok to bowl after 4 weeks, so I went ahead and bowled. I never felt any pain, or discomfort during, or after bowling, so just don't know. Life is now much better with catheter in. All the severe crotch pain is gone, along with the burning pain upon urination. What a relief that is. This Foley catheter is somewhat different from the one installed at time of surgery. Just what the difference is, I am not sure, but it is really not noticeable 90% of the time. Just so much more comfortable using this catheter. I just have to watch how full the travel bag is during the day. I nearly over filled it. I make it a point to lube the penis tip several times during the day, so it does not get irritated as it did with the Foley installed at time of surgery. So far, so good. Thanks for the words of encouragement. I appreciate that.

Posts.Content: Welcome to this forum. Everyone here to help anyway we can. I had RP surgery a year ago, and found it was not a painful situation. Sure, you will be sore afterwards, but not hard to live with. Suggest you read the sticky note at the near top of this forum called "What I Need to Know About Da Vinci surgery." It is really helpful to read the reaction of others who have been down this road. There are also some good videos on RP surgery that are highly educational.Suggest you ask hospital nurse for a 'Belly band" after surgery.It is an elastic band that you wrap around your mid section, that secures with its own velcro. Keeping it tight around your mid section gives added support, and lessens soreness during any body movement. Good luck on yout upcoming surgery.

Posts.Title: Premature worrying?

Posts.Content: From my experience.........lube the tip of the catheter at the end of your Johnson. You can even pull out the catheter tube about a quarter inch or so. When pulled out, lube the tube, then push it back inside your Johnson to better lube yourself. That is far better then just lubbing the very tip of your Johnson. Any time you feel a need, lube the catheter as much and as often as you like. If you change catheter bags, I found it far better to use the small travel bag during all waking hours. I wore shorts, so the catheter empty control valve would just barely stick out the bottom of the shorts. This made it very easy to empty urine, and a lot easier then carrying a bucket around the neighborhood. I did both approaches, and found the small bag much easier to manage. When transferring from small bag to large bag, I found it easier to do so in the bath tub. Any urine spills were much easier to clean up in the bath tub, as opposed to bathroom hard wood floor or carpet. If you are sleeping in a bed alone as I do, I found it better to lay the catheter collection bag on the bed beside me. I used a rubberized mattress cover, so any urine spill would not soak into the mattress. I never had a spill, and found the extra length of the drain tube gave me much more freedom to lay different ways in bed, particularly being able to sleep on my side. I used extra pillows placed on both sides of my body to keep from rolling over or around too much in the bed. Overall this is a much better experience, then hooking the collection bag to the side of the bed rail, or laying it on the floor. It does not allow much body movement in bed. I had to wear a Foley catheter for a total of 21 days over two episodes, so during that time, I had plenty of time to experiment to see what wearing improvements I could find to make Foley catheter life just a little better and easier. Hope some of these ideas help you and others. Get well soon...........Rooster

Posts.Title: 5 Days post op

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear that you have prostate cancer. All of us here have, or have had to face the same problem. Lots of good support from people who care, so hope we can give you good advise and support. You mention in your post that your uro has performed many "open prostatectomies." On your profile you list "RRP scheduled for 09/14/2016." I don't know what RRP stands for, but I hope it is not open prostatectomy. That surgery approach is really old fashion, and really only done if the patient is unable to have Da Vinci type surgery because of previous abdominal surgery, as in hernia repair. The old open surgery will keep you in the hospital as a patient for a week in severe pain. Da Vinci surgery gets you released from the hospital the next day with minimal surgical incision work, and a lot less pain, plus a much quicker recovery. As discussed above, moving to surgery in a hurry is not necessary. You don't have much prostate cancer, and what you have grows very slowly, and you probably would not have much more of it, if tested again at the end of the year. With your minimal cancer amount you may also be a good candidate for one of the radiation approaches. Cure rates are about the same with radiation vs surgery. I suggest you take time to get multiple opinions to decide what is best for you. You have plenty of time to do this. Let us know how you are coming along. We care.

Posts.Content: Radiation treatment does not automatically cause incontinence. Do you have other issues causing incontinence before radiation? A rectal balloon can be installed before each treatment. Not painful, just uncomfortable. It is used to push part of the rectum out of the way of radiation. I used it, and glad I did. Not all docs recommend it, you may have to ask for it. I had a scheduled colonoscopy about 4 months post radiation. The doctor said nothing about seeing anything abnormal, so I don't think that radiation is a factor during colonoscopy. Suggest you go to the Frank Talk Forum. www.franktalk.org That forum deals with primarily ED. I read through their topic on penile implants, and remember one guy posting that he had the implant and AUS. Check it out!
Posts.Title: artificial sphincter

Posts.Content: Like Michigan Man 16, I too was diagnosed as PT3B, and received the triple wammy of surgery, 8 weeks of radiation, and am close to concluding 18 months of hormone therapy. He told me that the HT is to put any micro metastatic pc cells that may have migrated through my body into hibernation. In hibernation, the pc cells won't multiply, and hopefully die off a natural death from old age. My uro/surgeon said it gives me the best chance of being cured of Pca. That said, I was told that this gives me about an 80% chance of a cure. Should it reoccur, I will be on hormone therapy for the rest of my life.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH I'm not sure, but I don't think Cialis would work as far as erections go if the nerves were not spared. However, prostatectomy patients usually are given a one-month supply of it (probably a low, 5 mg dose) to simply help enrich the blood flow to the surgical field. This helps speed up the healing process from the surgery, itself. Afterward, the Cialis probably would not be needed anymore. Once again, I'm not 100% certain, but I think injections would be the route to take in having future erections since the nerves were not spared. Either that or a surgical implant. Good luck! Chuck Highlander............you are spot on with your med knowledge and cialis treatment. Yes, I got the 30 day low 5 mg dose of cialis as you surmised. I am taking the drug as advised, perhaps it will enhance blood flow to aid healing, guess it can't hurt. With nerves NOT spared, no amount of cialis will ever help me achieve a natural woodie. Was surprised that my Urology surgeon called in a massive order of Cialis to my pharmacy without my knowledge. Pharmacy simply called me saying the script was ready for pick up. Cost was to be $379, but have a $200 discount Cialis coupon. This was all arranged prior to surgery. What a waste of $ and Cialis towards treating NON spared nerves. I declined the Cialis order, and felt the doc was too pushy in prescribing the drug. Made me wonder if he has an ulterior motive for prescribing, like being on a rewards program by prescribing Cialis mfg. by Eli Lilly Company, who makes Cialis. Whatever, the Cialis prescription was unwarranted, and not helpful.

Posts.Content: Yes, I am feeling better. I did not need to use the cold pack on my crotch yesterday. Still some discomfort while doing simple things like taking dogs for a walk. Just walking sets the sore spot in motion. At the re-attach junction, there is one specific spot that causes all the trouble. Irritate that spot, and it fights back with an increasing burning ache. That ache increases upon urination. Think bowling may be what set it off a month after surgery, but don't know for sure. I am not bowling, or playing racquet ball until this problem is fixed. Taking a steroid, and nerve pain med probably helping recovery, but taking it easy and time, are probably helping the most. Thanks to all for the kind words of encouragement.

However, I have doubts that will do me any good with no nerves. Any thoughts??
Posts.Title: Is Cialis right for me??

Posts.Content: Guess I got too optimistic too soon. Today, after going to a meeting, then shopping, the pain slowly began to return, and grow in strength as I shopped. Back to bed quickly upon returning home, with the cold pack in my crotch to ease the pain. I am now wondering if something went amiss when the urethra was rejoined to the bladder. The flair up of pain seems to start from one very specific pin point spot that always seems irritated, even on a good day. This makes me wonder if a misplaced surgical suture is the source of the problem? After last Friday's painful cystocopy procedure, I don't want to think forward to any additional procedures if needed to fix this problem. I advised my surgeon's triage nurse of my latest problem, who will advise my surgeon, and am hoping for the best.
Posts.Title: Six weeks since Di Vinci, now a problem

Posts.Content: Developed strong pain that first thought was a urinary tract infection by my family doctor, but test proved negative. So returned to my uro/surgeon in great pain last Friday. He did a cystocopy procedure on me in his office. Result is a problem where urethra is surgically rejoined at the bladder. That connection is slightly pulled loose, or pulled to one side, or something like that. There is no urine leakage at the site. I don't know if I did this with too much physical activity, or just what has caused this. Result is great soreness at the rejoined juncture, and one sore crotch. I am now on nerve pain med, a steroid, and pill that makes my urine turn blue. I was also given a prescription for oxy pain med, but not taking it. In hindsight, I seem to have this problem to some degree since surgery. I would have the soreness, but then it would subside. I thought with healing it would just go away, but no, it rises up strong at week 5 and persists. Doc says that the site should settle down on its on, and cure itself with time. In the meanwhile, an ice pack to my crotch is my best friend. Something tells me that this is going to take some time to heal. Anyone else had, or know of someone with this problem? Would like to know their story. Thanx!

Posts.Content: Congrats on the .01 PSA. Doesn't get any better then that. I had radiation following TURP like you, plus hormone therapy. Don't be surprised if Radiation Oncologist will want you to use a rectal balloon during radiation. It is somewhat uncomfortable having it inserted, but once inside, it doesn't feel bad. It really helps push a good portion of the colon out of the path of the radiation beam to keep the colon from being radiated. A good radiation machine is the Varian Rapid Arc. Hope you get treated by one of those. Good luck on your treatment. Keep us posted on your progress.

Posts.Content: When I got "marked up" for radiation therapy, I though for sure that I would get the freckle tattoos. But no, my radiation group simply marked me with a permanent felt tip marker, then applied surgical tape over the marking. I was told to leave the tape on, but after a few weeks, it started coming loose. No problem, new tape was applied, and radiation continued. Like others, the "marks" were used to line me up on the radiation table via laser beams. I had a custom molded tray created to lay my butt in. That is so you will remain in that position through out the treatment, and not move around. Has the RO promoted your having a rectal balloon installed per each treatment to move a portion of the bowel out of the way during radiation?

Posts.Content: Somewhere in all my forum readings, I read that someone was using an estrogen skin patch called Estrodiale. I am not sure that I have spelled it correctly. Posts.Title: Estrogen use with ADT

Posts.Content: Howrah on scoring a .01. That is terrific. I too, have been rated as pT3b pN0. I started HT 4 months before starting 8 weeks of radiation. It is believed that HT puts any remaining cancer cells into a state of hibernation, and into a weaker condition, so that radiation is more effective in treating cancer cells. Best wishes for low psa scores in the future.
Posts.Title: 6 Week Post-Op PSA results

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by white08gt I keep a close check on my testosterone, took about 6 months for it to get in the 400 range after HT. Then it started the slow gradual down hill slide, now no sign of it coming back up. The twins are shrinking, PSA still zero and considering going replacement TT. HT was extra hard on me, loss of muscle mass, body hair along with getting gynecomastia. Fun to go get a a mammogram and develop lumps in your breast. Do not take the 6 month shot, my new Uro suggested monthly or 3 month where you can take a break. I am with Creekrat, the SRT was easier than HT to me and did both at same time. Was told that I would need to be on HT for 3 years but opted out, so far so good. Met with my radiologist MD after radiation therapy. Agree that RT is easier then HT, as rectal baloon is so disagreeable. Radiologist plan in conjunction with my Uro-surgeon is for me to be on Ht (Eligard) for a total period of 2 years. This is because I had a Gleason 5 reading at time of surgery, and PSA started to edge up after surgery. The thought of 2 years of HT is depressing. I am at 5 months of HT, and hate being without testosterone. Doc says at the end of two years, the castrating effects of Eligard have set in, so negligible chance of testosterone recovery after stopping Eligard. The thought of no testosterone for the rest of my life is really depressing. I will be getting a second opinion from another urologist soon to see if 2 years of HT is needed, or if the 2 years is really a medical over kill.
Posts.Title: hormone therapy side effects after 2 years

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee I saw my RO yesterday. The plan now is to get a 3-month Lupron shot in early July when the AMS800 is activated, then begin IMRT in mid-August thru mid October. If the AUS requires tweaking we'll adjust the schedule as needed. He said no balloon... bring out the party hats! BTW my PSA is still <.03, sig updated. Recommend you ask for the balloon. It really helps move part of your bowel out of the way, when radiation is directed toward the prostate area. The less damaging radiation to the bowel the better. Glad I had the balloon.

Posts.Content: The Foley catheter does not have to be a dreaded experience. I had responded to an earlier post with this response, and figured a repost may be of value to you............. Some advise regarding the foley catheter. It helps to keep the tube entering your Johnson clean and well lubricated. Don't use rubbing alcohol for cleaning, just some very mild soap. You will be able to withdrawal the catheter tube a little more then a quarter inch. Lube the tube, and gently push the tube back into your Johnson. I did this whenever I felt irritation. Sometimes, I must have lubed the tube about 6 times per day. If you do this, wearing the foley is so much easier, and irritation free. After a while, I would forget that the catheter was still in use. I also found that sleeping with the catheter bag next to me on the bed worked much better then hanging the bag on the side of bed, or resting on the floor. With the bag on the bed, it is so much easier, and convenient to move around in bed. I had a plastic mattress cover on the bed to prevent any urine ever reaching the mattress in case of an accident. I never did have an accident. The bag is still lower then the rest of your body, so you won't have any reverse flow of urine back to your bladder. I never had any problems with urine filling the bag. This was all done with my sleeping alone on a full size bed. Hope my advise is of value, and wish you quick healing.

Posts.Content: Hi Dan.......how my RALP a year ago. Never had any blood in my urine, so I had no issue with it. Yes, better ask your doctor for his advise. Glad all is going well.

Posts.Title: Recovering now from my surgery

Posts.Content: Surgery is on August 3rd, Cath removal is 8 days later on August 11th. Sorry, I didn't make that inclusive in my first post. My particulars: Reside: Indianapolis, In Age: 71 PSA History: PSA 20 months ago at 4.2, then had a physical with my family doctor. PSA jumped to 7.4, so referred to a urologist. Subsequent PSA score was 7.2, with 10% free PSA Biopsy results: 10 out of 12 cores cancerous, some severely so. Gleason score of 8. Some cancer cells may be in seminal vessels and lymph nodes. I understand that tissue is examined during surgery to determine where cancer cells may be located and removed. Thank God, bone scan results were negative. Rationale for opting for Rad Prostatectomy........way too much cancer in prostate. Investigated radiation, but don't feel comfortable with radiation collateral damage done to adjacent tissue. Weeks and weeks of radiation 5 times a week seems arduous. Surgery is Da Vinci assisted Was referred to a Urologist by a friend. He did the diagnostic work, then referred me to a surgeon in his Urology group. I also got a second opinion from another surgical urologist, who highly recommended the Da Vinci surgery. Don't know how many RPs Uro surgeon has done, but know he is highly regarded by other doctors, and has been during Da Vinci surgery for at least 10 years. Doctor is rather arrogant and aloof. I have encountered this behavior before with other surgeons. They must go to med school to learn this behavior. Not someone that I want to be friends with, or friendly towards, I am just hiring him to do good surgery work on me. Already doing kegel exercises, and sit ups. I am having my surgery 2 weeks after my wife has had knee replacement surgery. My first week home after surgery is going to be difficult for both of us. We have friends helping by looking in on us, and bringing us meals. My wife and I are calling this the "summer of surgery." Things are bound to get better for the both of us.
Posts.Title: August 3rd, I meet Mr. Da Vinci

Posts.Content: Not exactly staying on topic........but have read about guys receiving the artificial sphincter, have simultaneously, received a penile implant to restore penis erection, if ED is a problem from prostate surgery procedure. That way two problems are corrected via one surgery.
Posts.Title: Need advice on artificial sphincter

Posts.Content: I have been on Eligard, which is the same as Lupron, just a different brand name of the product for the past year. With me, I tolerate it okay. It is the hot flashers that are the most bothersome. About 80% of users experience this. I take Venlafaxine to reduce the hot flash effect, and it cuts hot flash intensity by about 50%. The other issue, is that Eligard/Lupron reduces bone calcium. I off set that with calcium pills, but then have constipation issues. The drug is also mood altering. I seem to have less patience with everything and everybody. There is also a strong tendency to put on belly fat. and there is also loss of muscle to some degree, and loss of stamina or endurance. I exercise more at the gym to combat muscle loss. I hope to be off Eligard at the end of November, and hope my testosterone level will regenerate to pre Eligard usage.
