Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MRJ Just a note on the Vasoline: Some sites say it it okay to use and even go as far as to suggest Vasoline as a lubricant for the Foley catheter. Other sites make the case that Vasoline, due to being petroleum based, can damage the catheter. In one study, the effects of 4 different lubes were tried on Foley catheters over the period of 5 days. Each lube was tested with 20 catheters each. At the end of 5 days, there were 20 catheter balloon ruptures, all of them involved the catheters where the Vasoline was used. Yes, petroleum based products like Vaseline can degrade plastic. However, in this case, the use of Vaseline at the tip of your johnson is at a considerable distance from the catheter balloon located inside the bladder. I don't see any possibility that the Vaseline could ever enter the bladder to affect the balloon. When I used the Vaseline, I saw no damage to the plastic catheter tubing after 10 days of use.
Posts.Title: Very Sensitive Urethra, Apparently

Posts.Content: Bulldog..............I had 8 weeks of EBRT with the rectal balloon. My radiation oncologist in charge of my radiation treatment recommended it. I am glad it was incorporated into my treatment. It is designed to move a portion of the colon out of the path of the radiation treatment, thus saving a portion from unnecessary radiation. The insertion of the balloon devise is not painful, just somewhat uncomfortable. Once installed, there is no discomfort at all. Sometimes during radiation, I would fall asleep, to give you an idea of no discomfort. After a while, the daily insertion of the balloon becomes normal to what you expect of the treatment. There is a difference among techs, as to who inserts the balloon. Some are really good at it, so it is gently inserted easily, while others have a rougher technique, which you will learn not to appreciate. It did not take long for me to learn who was the gentalist, and I would ask that, that tech install the balloon. The removal of the balloon is super easy, and not uncomfortable at all. EBRT becomes like a part time job, in that you get a treatment Monday thru Friday. I generally would show up about 45 minutes prior to my appointment, so I could better regulate having a full bladder. If needed to fill bladder more, I would drink more water, if too full, I would go to the bathroom to pee for just 2 or 3 seconds. Often, I would get my treatment prior to appointment time, which was alright with me. Good luck with your radiation. It is not difficult. I think you will easily adjust to having the balloon installed.
Posts.Title: Your experience rectal balloon with EBRT

Posts.Content: Met with my uro-surgeon last Thursday. I had Da Vinci 3 months ago, with a slow painful recovery because of lymphocels. I am healing much better now, but latest PSA test produced a 0.22 read out. Doc says that number denotes I still have some PCa. Latest plan is to receive Eligard injections once a month for 6 months. This will put the PCa into remission, and give my surgery additional time to heal, before receiving radiation to kill off PCa. Doctor said side effects of reduced testosterone produced by Eligard, is hot flashes, fatigue, and low sexual desire. At an Eligard website, I found additional effects listed, with numerical percentages. Hot flashes -- in up to 73.3 percent of people Injection site reactions, including mild pain, burning, and stinging -- up to 34.6 percent Fatigue and general discomfort -- up to 17.5 percent Decreased testicle size -- up to 7.2 percent Muscle pain -- up to 4.5 percent Dizziness -- up to 4.4 percent Clamminess -- up to 4.4 percent Weakness -- up to 3.6 percent Breast enlargement -- up to 3.6 percent Nausea -- up to 3.4 percent Joint pain -- up to 3.4 percent. Other common reactions, occurring in 2.2 to 3.3 percent of people, included: Decreased libido (decreased sex drive) Night sweats Pain in the arms or legs Frequent need to urinate Itching Stomach and intestinal irritation ("stomach flu") Getting up in the middle of the night to urinate Hair loss Testicular pain. I would like to hear any testimonials from anyone who has received Eligard. Thanks...........Rooster22
Posts.Title: Advise on Lupron (Eligard) usage

Posts.Content: As mentioned in second thread on same subject, I failed to mention that Eligard was the drug for hormone treatment. I got to thinking some users would not know that. I don't think my uro/surgeon failed. I knew in advance of surgery, that it was likely that my PCa had spread a little out of my prostate, and that radiation would be most likely to kill off any cancer cells remaining in the pelvic area. My slow recovery from surgery with lymphocel pain, an additional 2 weeks of Foley Cather, plus 2 illnesses during recovery all add up to the doctor saying that another six months of healing is in my best interest before radiation. The hormone therapy is a way to put the PCa into sleep mode remission, and to stop, or at least slow down cancer growth. I trust my doctor's plan, and trust I will beat PC with time. Thanks fl drifter (David) for your testimonial of your 6 month experience with hormone therapy. None of the side effects sound good, but at least manageable. I have already promised myself to fight through any fatigue, control my diet against gaining weight, and resigned myself to no sex drive. I do hope if my testes shrink, that they will return to normal in due time. I also hope my testosterone level will rebound to normal.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by white08gt Well, I had all the side effects listed in your first post. You will not have any testosterone, it will be zero. Do the monthly shots, definitely don't take the 6 month. I opted out of HT some 6 months following SRT. My PSA has been <0.05 for close to 2 years and testosterone is in 200s and has not rebounded as have the twins. I will take your advise regarding a monthly shot vs the shot good for 6 months. I just started the monthly shot last week, so side effects are probably weeks ahead for me. If side effects get to troublesome, I may opt out early from the 6 month recommendation given me by the doctor. The doctor told me that the reason for the HT is to give me extra time to recover from the DaVinci surgery about 3 months ago. I may not need the extra healing time before starting radiation therapy to kill off cancer cells not removed during surgery. Also, the thought of testicle size reduction, and potential low testosterone production after HT is not something I want to be left with. I have started taking the calcium and vitamin D supplements to help prevent bone weakening

Posts.Content: Bulldog, unsure what you mean by SBRT. What type of treatment is this? Regarding ADT, there is an excellent sticky note that is the second from the top listing of topics, when signing on to this forum. It is titled........"What I Need to Know About HT", which is ADT. Myself, I have been on ADT for 15 months of an 18 month sentence. It is tolerable, but uncomfortable with daily hot flashes, some fatigue, and loss of endurance. It really depends on how long you will be on ADT to feel side effects. The longer, the more side effects encountered. Beyond maybe 6 months, it is a battle of watching your diet. If you are less active, then reduce your calorie intake, or you will put on weight, and all that weight will become belly fat. It is important to stay active, with weight bearing exercise to ward off bone loss, and the weight gain. Also, ADT can affect your temperament. I don't have much patience now, and am irritable at times. Again, exercise will help your temperament, so best to be active. There are a host of other side effects, that are not as common. Reading the sticky note, will tell you about them. I had surgery, not seeds, so I have no knowledge regarding see treatment. Good luck, I hope all goes well.

Posts.Title: 5 months post surgery update

Posts.Content: Saw this response to another thread, and thought it may be of value to your..................... Given the low volume you have, you may want to consider another option between AS and surgery: focal HIFU, which is sometimes called a "male lumpectomy" where the tumor is ablated (i.e., cooked) via ultrasound, but most of the remaining prostate is spared and remains functional. I've posted information on HIFU under the "Sticky" at the top of the page if you would like to review the pros and cons. I reviewed the panel discussion on HIFU at the AUA conference, and there seems to be more enthusiasm for focal HIFU than for HIFU of the entire prostate. Focal was not an option for me because both lobes had tumors, but if I had only 5% involved, I would have investigated that treatment. If you do decide to look into HIFU, I strongly encourage you to seek out a urologist who has had substantial experience in HIFU. The procedure was only approved by the FDA in Oct. 2015 (although approved in Europe and Japan for 10-15 years) and lots of urologists are now offering HIFU. The US uro's with the most experience were doing HIFU treatment before 10/15 by doing treatments in Bemuda and other Carribean locations

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by oshguy The imaging done prior to catheter removal is standard procedure with my surgeon at the Cleveland Clinic. It's a very simple and fast procedure to determine that the anasthemosis of the urethra does not leak. The bladder is filled with a dye solution through the catheter, the radiologist watches the screen for a few seconds, the fluid is allowed to drain, and you're on your way. If no leaks, then the catheter can be removed. This makes a lot of sense, so I will expect to do this test. Hope it is not painful or uncomfortable. I bet this is no time to be modest. I bet my little guy will be on full display for all to see. Just not comfortable with this happening.

Posts.Content: When I started my radiation earlier this year, I was fortunate enough to have a friend whose job is to continually adjust performance of radiation equipment at clinics and hospitals. He advised me where to go for treatment, because they had the latest state of the art equipment. He advised getting treatment with the Varian Rapid Arc equipment. You may want to consider asking each center what equipment they have. Also, it is important to know that radiation equipment, and technique has advanced considerably in the past 15 years. Now, the equipment focuses very precisely, with less radiation to internal organs. Ask to have the rectal balloon if available. That helps protect the colon from radiation. Be aware that radiation is done with a nearly full to full bladder, so driving a long distance can be a bladder concern. Weeks of radiation gets to feel like a part time job. Time passes quicker then you may think, and then you are done. Hope all goes well.
Posts.Title: Who to choose for radiation?

Posts.Content: Agree, cystoscopy is very painful, at least for me. First time I had one, I had no idea how bad it was going to be. Doc applied just a little lidocaine at the tip of the penis only, and had a nurse put a cold wet paper towel on my forehead. The paper towel did little to take my mind off the pain. Two weeks later, I had another cystoscopy, and got prepared for it by taking two Oxycontin pain tablets before showing up at the doctor's office. The pain pills helped make the procedure tolerable. I never bothered to tell the doctor about taking the pain pills, as I didn't think he was interested in my pain. As far as using a Foley catheter, I found it better to lube the tip of your johnson with any type of cream including vasoline. Do so any time you start to feel irritation. For me, I was probably lubbing 6-8 times per day. It helps to slightly pull out the catheter slightly until resistance is met. Clean the crud that forms on the catheter tube, lube the tube and end of your johnson, then with light pressure push the tube back into your johnson. Doing that made life so much better. Don't know why someone at doc's office didn't offer that advise. All that was said, was keep the tip clean, and use some cream.

Two weeks later, I had another cystoscopy, and got prepared for it by taking two Oxycontin pain tablets before showing up at the doctor's office. The pain pills helped make the procedure tolerable. I never bothered to tell the doctor about taking the pain pills, as I didn't think he was interested in my pain. As far as using a Foley catheter, I found it better to lube the tip of your johnson with any type of cream including vasoline. Do so any time you start to feel irritation. For me, I was probably lubbing 6-8 times per day. It helps to slightly pull out the catheter slightly until resistance is met. Clean the crud that forms on the catheter tube, lube the tube and end of your johnson, then with light pressure push the tube back into your johnson. Doing that made life so much better. Don't know why someone at doc's office didn't offer that advise. All that was said, was keep the tip clean, and use some cream.
Posts.Title: Very Sensitive Urethra, Apparently

Posts.Content: I recently completed 19 months of hormone therapy with Eligard. Eligard is exactly the same product as Lupron, just made by a different manufacturer. All posts on this thread are spot on correct. The side effects of Eligard/Lupron can be fully read by googling "Lupron side effects." It is interesting to note that probably most of the side effects are really from developing low testosterone. If you google "low testosterone side effects," you will read the side effects are nearly identical to "Lupron side effects." The upside of Lupron is that it puts cancer cells into hibernation (but does not kill them) by denying them testosterone, that helps them grow, divide, and multiply. During that hibernation, it is hoped the cancer cells will die of old age. The down side of Lupron is that it is chemical castration. It cannot be accurately be determined, but taken over time, you will never be able to produce as much testosterone as you did before taking Lupron. My radiation oncologist told me that I can expect only about a 20% return of my previous level of testosterone before treatment. My urologist spoke to me about getting testosterone treatments, but that is controversial, in that may activate prostate cancer cells once again.
Posts.Title: One year on Lupron

Posts.Content: Like you, I am stage T3, with no. It is my understanding that when cancer spreads outside the prostate, the spread is right into the seminal vesicles. From there, it spreads to the lymph nodes. I have read that the real danger is spread throughout the body from the lymph nodes. IMO, I don't think the risk of spread from the seminals is much of a problem. Others on this forum may know much better.

Posts.Content: Here is a link to a website to a clinical study addressing shorter time on ADT for those originally scheduled to be on hormone therapy for 2 or 3 years. In my case, I was scheduled for two years. My uro/surgeon vacated my sentence to 19 months. My quality of life is getting much better since the end of May, when 3 months shot expired. The study showed that a shorter time on ADT is statistically the same result, as if on ADT for a longer period of time. https://www.practiceupdate.com/conte.../70469/61/11/1
Posts.Title: For those on long term hormone therapy (ADT)

Posts.Content: IMHO, you won't have that much actual pain after the Da Vinci, but your abdomen will be very sore for about the first 3 days. All pain comes from abdominal soreness. You will probably spend one night at the hospital. Ask for an abdominal wrap from a nurse. It will be about 12" wide, and wraps around your abdomen and fastens upon itself with velcro. It helps a lot to limit movement in your abdomen, and thus reduce pain. For the first few days, you will not want to cough or sneeze, as it will cause a lot of pain. If you feel a sneeze coming on, use both hands to push in your abdomen to help control the pain. On my bed, I added an extra mattress on top of my existing mattress to raise the height of the bed to make it easy to enter and exit. The issue is that it is painful to bend down much that first three days. Standard instruction is to lay the catheter bag on the floor next to the bed. I did that for a while, but found it easier to move around on the bed with the catheter bag lying next to me on the bed. I used a rubberized water proof mattress cover in case of any leakage, but never had a problem. I slept alone in a bed, so for me, I positioned myself more towards the center of the bed, and used pillows on both sides of my body to keep from rolling over, so I could sleep on my back. Within a few days, I was able to sleep on my side, and roll over a bit. The catheter bag lying beside me on the bed gave me plenty of urine drainage tube length to move around. I sleep a lot better on my side, so I was glad to be able to figure that out. Use stool softners and laxatives frequently when taking any codeine based pain reliever, as codeine will make you constipated. Failure to do so will result in a hard stool that will be painful and difficult to pass. Try to walk as much as you can immediately following surgery, and during the first week following surgery. This helps to clear your lungs to ward off potential pneumonia and blood clots. When walking my neighborhood with the large urinary bag, I used a cloth shopping bag with cloth handles to carry the bag. It looked a lot better, and was easier then using a bucket with a bail handle. Overall, Da Vinci is not that bad. It is not that painful, and recovery is mostly over by the end of the first week. Good luck on your surgery, we are all here to help you.
Posts.Title: Surgery Date Confirmed

Posts.Content: That has always been the problem. The immune system fails to recognize anything wrong with cells that have divided and mutated into cancer. Immunotherapy is where cancer will be cured at the cellular level in the future. Until then, cancer treatment is crude and barbaric in MHO. All we have now is cutting cancer out (surgery,) burning cancer out with radiation, or selectively poisoning out cancer with chemo. All crude treatments. Twenty-five years from now, people will look back at 2017 cancer treatment in dismay. I am on ADT to kill off suspected stray cells, but not sure ADT really kills cancer cells, but really just puts them into hibernation, so they don't grow and spread. Maybe existing cancer cells simply die off with ADT from old age.

Posts.Content: From what I have read, it is difficult to get up from a sitting or lying position after DaVinci surgery. I remember how sore my abdomen was in this regard, when recovering from umbilical hernia surgery years back. I am doing DaVinci surgery on August 3rd. and strongly suspect much worse soreness abdominal pain compared to the hernia recovery. I am thinking of using snow ski poles to help hoist myself out of a chair, or up from a bed. I have practiced this a few times with the ski poles, and the strain on the abdomen is much reduced when using your shoulder muscles to pull yourself up. Has anyone tried this, or similar after DaVinci?? I have given some thought about sleeping on a recliner as suggested on this forum, but with my wife is recovering from knee replacement surgery, and she will be unable to move the recliner from the reclined position to regular upright chair position. So, don't think a recliner is the way to go. I am thinking our bed is better choice, and using the poles to help get up. Any thoughts or suggestions?? Rooster2
Posts.Title: Use snow ski poles during DaVinci surgery recovery

Posts.Content: Finished 8 weeks of RT in mid April, after RT last August of 16. Last week of RT felt irritation upon urination. A week after finishing RT irritation became burning pain, then within a few weeks it became pelvic pain. After my urologist ran tests, he could not find anything wrong. To me, it was becoming pretty obvious the problem was from the RT. Pretty sure the problem is with the urethra only, specifically at the sphincter muscle. My bladder seems unaffected. The very small area just felt "cooked" inside and out. Just a week ago, my uro doctor had me start taking Alive, 2 tablets in the morning, 2 tablets at night. I am surprised the burning pain subsided greatly within 24 hours. After a week, I am now down to one Aleve in the morning, one Aleve at night. My remaining issue now is occasional bouts of intense need to urinate even when my bladder is not full. Seems worse when I bend over at the waist. Has anyone else had this side effect from RT? If so, how long did it last before fading away? Thanks, Rooster2
Posts.Title: Dysuria (painful urination) after external beam radiation

Posts.Content: Sounds like you have had a Foley catheter installed. Hard to believer you left the doctor's office without someone giving you a tube of lube to be used as a lube where the tube enters your penis. Most any kind of ointment helps, even Vasoline to take away the irritation. My last Foley was installed for 2 weeks, and the lube became my best friend. What works great is to know that the tube can be withdrawn maybe up to a third of an inch by gently pulling on the tube. Once pulled out, coat the tube with an ointment, and gently push it back into your penis. Doing this pulls the lube back inside of your pecker to soothe the irritation. Do this as often as you feel irritation. When applied often, a crud will tend to build up on the tube. When tube is pulled outward, clean off the crud with water and a kleenex, then apply more lubricant. Don't use alcohol to clean the tube. Once you start using lube, you won't need the pain killers you are taking. Using lots of lube, I found it stopped all irritation, and I would forget I had the Foley in me. I also found it a lot easier to sleep by putting the urine catch bag beside me in bed. Having it on the floor beside the bed was too movement restrictive for me. I never had a problem of urine leakage on the mattress. Hope my advise helps!
Posts.Title: Catheter pain

Posts.Content: Glad to hear that things are going well. Some advise regarding the foley catheter. It helps to keep the tube entering your Johnson clean and well lubricated. Don't use rubbing alcohol for cleaning, just some very mild soap. You will be able to withdrawal the catheter tube a little more then a quarter inch. Lube the tube, and gently push the tube back into your Johnson. I did this whenever I felt irritation. Sometimes, I must have lubed the tube about 6 times per day. If you do this, wearing the foley is so much easier, and irritation free. After a while, I would forget that the catheter was still in use. I also found that sleeping with the catheter bag next to me on the bed worked much better then hanging the bag on the side of bed, or resting on the floor. With the bag on the bed, it is so much easier, and convenient to move around in bed. I had a plastic mattress cover on the bed to prevent any urine ever reaching the mattress in case of an accident. I never did have an accident. The bag is still lower then the rest of your body, so you won't have any reverse flow of urine back to your bladder. I never had any problems with urine filling the bag. This was all done with my sleeping alone on a full size bed. Hope my advise is of value, and wish you quick healing.
Posts.Title: Back home

Posts.Content: both my uro doc, and RO thought I had a urethra stricture, or a mass in my bladder as the cause of the problem. So had that "looked into" under general anesthesia for out patient surgery. I came to thinking I would have a foley catheter to put up with, and the problem solved. But no, doc found nothing wrong. So, had a CT scan and body bone scan. All results were negative. Only thing really left was to think the problem was caused by radiation. At that point my doc said to drink lots of water. I found that helped the dysuria, I already knew that if I became dehydrated, as was mandated for the out patient surgery, that the pain would be terrific. Upon getting prepped for surgery, the pain was so bad, that I was given to shots of morphine in the saline drip tube to control the pain. I think my problem is rather rare. I have read several cancer forums, and no one has had my problem. Still, if anyone knows about this, I would like to hear from them. I am still not over this problem, and would like to know how much more time it will take to end this recovery episode.
Posts.Title: Dysuria (painful urination) after external beam radiation

Posts.Content: Saw my uro surgeon for 3 month visit. I asked him what the slight lump was on my abdomen. He said it is a small hernia, that has developed at the site at or near the incision. It is small, doesn't hurt. Doctor thought it best to see a surgeon for an opinion of what to do, or not do. Well that is like asking your minister his advisement on members attending church service on Sunday. We all know what that answer to that will be. I had an umbilical hernia repaired years ago, so I know it is no big deal having out patient surgery for a repair. So, will probably get advised to get it fixed, because it could get larger, and cause a big problem in the future. I have read that RALP could result in a hernia, but don't think I have ever read on this forum of it happening. I did not do any heavy lifting, or strenuous exercise to cause the hernia, it just happened. Still, it is prudent to advise against activity that could cause a hernia while healing.

Posts.Title: Post surgery PT?

Posts.Content: I have never used lidocaine, so no comment on that product. However, I found that using a lubricant many times during the day would stop the burning irritation at the tip of my johnson. It is important to gently pull the tubing out of your johnson a good quarter inch or so. Then, clean off any crud that has formed on the tube. Lube the tube, and the end of your johnson and gently push the tube back into your johnson. The problem seems to be that guys don't lube often enough. At the first sign of any irritation, I would lube asap. As a result, I had minimal irritation, and didn't mind the Foley. Sometimes, I was lubbing 6-8 times a day. That worked great for me.

Posts.Content: In my situation, a tube was inserted to drain the Lymphocele. Once all fluid was drained, the tube was immediately drained. If like me, you will feel immediately better. The pain will be gone. In my case, the Lymphocele filled back up with fluid, and had to be drained two more times before healing up. I was told that it is unusual for the Lymphocele to fill up again with lymph fluid. Usually a single drain is all that is needed. From what I read, a Lymphocele can get infected, but not very likely, and don't think it will burst. Oh, re-read your original post. You already have a drain tube inserted. The doc will probably removed the tube, if nothing more is draining out. Your burning up peeing is what I had after 8 weeks of radiation. My uro-surgeon told me to drink lots and lots of water. That helped to lessen the pain, but it finally took mega doses of Aleve for a week to heal my radiated urethera, Hang in there, things will get better.

Posts.Content: Sounds like what you are dealing with is commonly known as diaper rash. There are a number of products sold to deal with diaper rash. I have used Vitamins A & D Ointment under the brand name of Equate, that is sold at Wal-Mart. It is an excellent product to treat diaper rash, and provides a barrier against wetness. I think it is important to clean yourself repeatedly to keep urine off your skin. Hope this info helps.

Posts.Title: Mr. Johnson is unhappy- ideas?

Posts.Content: Yes, I developed two Lymphoceles about 2 months after RP. Mine were very low in my abdomen. One of the Lymphocele pressed on a nerve to cause a lot of pain. It took my doc a while to figure out what was causing my pain. Treatment was done by inserting two drain tubes into the Lymphoceles. Lynocaine injection, and an IV with a pain killer were used at time of tube insertion. This was done under a cat scan, so doc could accurately insert the needle to the right spot. It was nearly painless. Unfortunately, after draining, the Lymphoceles filled back up with fluid, twice more, and had to be drained twice more. The last two sessions, the doc injected something into the Lymphoceles to seal off further drainage. That finally ended the Lymphoceles, and the pain. Lymphocele is something I had never heard of before. It is not very common according to my uro-surgeon, but do occur, when lymph nodes are removed during an RP. Somehow, the surgeon fails to seal off all lymph involved, so that is the source of the fluid leakage. Good luck to you on the 6th. It is pretty much an easy out patient procedure. It was easy to get up, and walk out of the hospital, with no pain or restrictions afterwards.
Posts.Title: Lymphocell

Posts.Content: You state..........."my Urologist wants to wait on treatment until my PSA takes a sharp jump upward, or I experience bone pain." Wait until bone pain??????? That doesn't sound right at all. Bone pain is thought of as strong indicator of metastasizing prostate cancer to the bone, and then is classed as stage 4 cancer. You never want to wait for that to happen. I agree with Brownie, suggest you get ADT to stop the growth, and progress of prostate cancer, and then find your way to treatment with a competent urologist. At age 73, you have Medicare, and hopefully a supplement package to fill Medicare gaps. Use that to find a competent urologist. Doesn't sound like the teaching college, or VA is where you should be for best treatment. At your age, you should still be eligible for prostate surgery, or external radiation, or other forms of radiation. You should not feel limited on treatments. Please post your progress. We are here to help you. Best regards, Larry (Rooster22)
